Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Documenting the Languages of Manang, Nepal for Local and International Impact

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
In an increasingly globalized world, indigenous minority languages, such as the tribal languages of Nepal's Manang District, are threatened by migration, the loss of younger speaker populations, and the influence of dominant majority cultures. This CAREER project undertakes a unique response to language endangerment by exploring innovative methods of language documentation that also involve and benefit diverse populations. The project encompasses collaborative, multi-institutional field investigations of the four tribal languages Nyeshangte, Gyalsumdo, Manang-Gurung and Nar-Phu in order to merge traditional documentation methods with cutting-edge visualization tools. Investigators will adapt approaches from other studies of language and dialect variation by building a web-accessible, multi-media atlas to chart the rich language histories, variation, and attitudes found in Manang. This output will represent a new approach to documentation, one with a geographic perspective to chart structural details, threats, survival scenarios and future prospects within and across these languages. The project will also provide essential learning tools about, and for, language endangerment and survival scenarios in Nepal. One focus group will be undergraduate university students, who represent influential global citizens who would otherwise encounter issues of endangerment and preservation only in a detached context of textbooks and lecture. Project methods will embrace a collaborative spirit, including work with Tribhuvan University in Kathmandu, and with trained assistants in the Manang District. The project will also involve work with colleagues and students in the Geographic Information Systems program at the home institution. University students are involved in all phases of data collection and analysis, and in the design of pedagogical materials. Additionally, the project will collaborate with archivists at the University of Virginia on long-term data preservation and visualization protocols. The goals, methods, and resources garnered from this project will provide an exciting and groundbreaking standard for future documentation, archival, educational, and language awareness endeavors.
This international project is funded by Cultural Anthropology, Documenting Endangered Languages, and the Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The National Science Foundation Documenting Endangered Languages program funded project BCS 1149639 "Documenting the Languages of Manang, Nepal for Local and International Impact" (CAREER). The primary goals of the project were to document selected aspects of four minority indigenous languages of the Manang District of Nepal in order to construct a database for vocabulary and grammatical comparison across the four languages, collect and archive data to facilitate a cross-linguistic analysis of the sound systems of the languages, and to record, transcribe, and archive parallel discourse texts to facilitate further linguistic and cultural analysis studies. Furthermore, another goal was to conduct sociolinguistic interviews with representative members of the language communities to allow for a measurable assessment of language vitality/attitudes, language contact effects, and language variation within and across the communities. The methods contributing to these goals and outputs also provided for community and student collaboration and training in methods of data collection, processing, and materials archival process.

The initial phase of the project involved fieldwork and data collection through audio and video recordings in Nepal. Undergraduate and graduate students from the PI's home institution were trained in ethical and practical considerations of community-engaged fieldwork and they received on-site mentoring and support while in Nepal. Upon completion of fieldwork, at the home institution, the students worked with the PI and with collaborators based at a field office in Nepal to transcribe materials and prepare them for archive. The students also worked with the PI to build a custom archival application at the home institution to house data and project outputs in digital form. Throughout the lifespan of the project, students and collaborators worked with the PI to co-construct a variety of outputs including digital resources (an interactive online atlas and a web page) and academic products (conference presentations, journal manuscripts, book chapters), for which they were included as co-authors.

The intellectual merit of this project includes the creation of an archival collection of naturalistic data to facilitate analysis of the various nuances and cross-community variation of these closely related languages, including their grammars and sound systems. It also includes comprehensive sociolinguistic interviews that model scenarios of monolingual and multilingual language practices, language attitudes, and language viability across communities in a region of intense social, economic, and political change. The intellectual merit also includes contributions to debates surrounding the genealogy and history of these languages within the larger Sino-Tibetan language family. Additionally, the texts represent genres that provide valuable information on the histories, social organization, and cultural traditions of these communities.

The broader impacts include both informal and formal training and mentoring to university students (undergraduate and graduate) on field research methods, on materials organization and processing, and on the use of these materials in their own scholarly projects that cross disciplines. Students also received professionalism training by their involvement in community networking, conference participation, and manuscript construction and revision. The broader impacts also include community members in Manang, Nepal. The community members were involved in the design and implementation of the project from the beginning. They helped to identify topics that would contribute to the archive of discourse texts, which would then foster learning about the cultures and histories of their communities. They also helped project collaborators learn about the intricacies of the grammatical systems of these languages from the collected data.

The resulting products and outcomes include several conference presentations and published manuscripts/articles/chapters that are of interest to broad academic audiences. The products also include two online archives, in which project materials are catalogued. Selected texts from these archives are also integrated into an online, interactive, multi-media atlas that charts the languages and language practices across Manang. The outputs also include a community-constructed dictionary of one of the languages: Gyalsumdo. This dictionary includes culturally important terms and images captured from Gyalsumdo communities. Paper copies were disseminated in 2016 to community members and for local schools. Another output is a published manuscript that describes pedagogy and curriculum materials, using methods and data from this project, to incorporate the teaching of endangered languages into undergraduate courses.

Over the short term, the impacts of this project include an archive of materials that are valuable for academic and community use. They also include professional training and mentorship for dozens of students at the home institution. Over the long term, this project enables/facilitates the PI and collaborators to continue working with materials towards ongoing publications and outputs. The transcribed and translated discourse text archive will serve as a valuable conduit of language practices and information about community traditions and histories for those Manang communities who no longer reside in the region, or who do not have full proficiency of their heritage languages.
